html:
NEW YORK, Feb 4 (IFR) - Handwringing about the direction of stocks, corporate earnings and the economy is completely overshadowing US ECM activity for now and there's little obvious catalyst for a near-term revival in issuance.

Though markets were more constructive this week (the S&P 500 rose 1.6% and the VIX fell 16% to 23.22 this week), this morning’s strong January job numbers did little to improve the outlook for ECM.

For one, 10-year Treasury bond yields rose to 1.92%, their highest since 2019.

Some speculated the Federal Reserve may lift interest rates by 50bps next month (futures have priced in a 30% chance of that outcome), though 25bps is still the consensus.

And yet while incoming eco data are generally still hot, the flattening yield curve this week sparked recession talk in some quarters, muddying the waters even more but maybe also reflecting the struggle to understand the impact of pandemic distortions.

Looking ahead, investors will have to grapple with another important inflation reading next week (the CPI release on Thursday, February 10).

More exciting for traders this week were the whipsawing moves in big tech stocks (check out Snap over recent days), perhaps highlighting the rising importance of stock-picking this year as the performance of big tech starts to diverge.

Amazon today posted the (or one of the) biggest daily market cap gains ever ($190bn) in the wake of its earnings beat, coming just a day after Facebook posted one of the biggest market cap losses ($230bn) following its disappointing quarter.

For the first time since early April 2020 (outside of holiday-interrupted weeks), the past week saw zero follow-ons raising more than $50m.

Bankers were still able to price two small IPOs, a $124m offering from biotech Arcellx (up 12% on debut) and a downsized $85m deal from BDC Silver Spike Investment (which closed its first session flat).

The progression of the quarterly earnings season through the halfway mark as of today (about 56% of S&P 500 companies have now reported) may create some secondary/follow-on opportunities next week, though the rank underperformance of key ECM contributors such as tech and healthcare counts out a lot of contenders.

Financials and the energy sector (oil prices crossed $90 a barrel this week for the first time since 2014) are relative outperformers this year and may provide some near-term deal prospects, though not anything like the volume produced by the most active sectors of recent years.

Neither is there a lot of obvious secondary candidates among last year’s struggling IPO class, though wholesale insurance broker Ryan Specialty (up two-thirds since it went public in July) and real estate private equity firm Bridge Investment (up 39%) are two that have done well and just crossed the six-month anniversary of their debuts.

Another IPO priced around the same time as these two is European Wax Center, which sponsor General Atlantic partly monetized via a first-time secondary in November (following the company’s early August IPO). The stock closed today’s session at $24.83, below the $26.25 price of that offering.

Overall ECM activity so far in 2022 is running more than 75% below the pace of last year.

Meanwhile, SPAC product, which was firing on all cylinders this time last year, has reached an inflection point where IPO filings are being withdrawn faster than deals are pricing.

Traditional IPO filings have also dried up in recent weeks, more evidence that February is going to be lean in terms of pricings.

There is a backlog of companies that have showed their hand and could theoretically proceed with their roadshows near-term, though the so-called "staleness" deadline on February 14 (meaning they can no longer rely on old accounts after this date) is another factor holding up launches near-term.

Car-sharing firm Turo, eye health company Bausch & Lomb and mattress retailer Mattress Firm are among the largest and most prominent IPOs on file publicly that hoped to launch and price early in the first quarter but have not done so.

As noted here several times in recent weeks, bankers have been advising most to delay their plans until markets stabilize.

Therapeutic value

Arcellx performed pretty much as expected on debut today, the New Enterprise Associates-backed cancer drug developer opening at $19.00 before fading to close at $16.80 for a respectable 12% gain.

Just 1.1m shares changed hands, or about 13% of the 8.25m-share base deal, highlighting just how tightly the deal was allocated.

A syndicate led by Bank of America, SVB Leerink, Barclays and William Blair told investors when the offering launched that it was oversubscribed with demand from existing shareholders. Indeed, they ended up placing 90% of the deal with VCs and other pre-IPO backers.

In a week that saw the Nasdaq Biotechnology gain ground for the first week in six, Arcellx’s early gains were another step in the sector's healing process after investors sustained some heavy losses on many of last year’s new issues.

CinCor Pharma, the largest of three other biotechs that have gone public in 2022, traded just 190,000 shares in today’s session, rising 6.7% to $20.36 and is now 27.3% above last month’s IPO price.

Arcellx now has $250m of funding for a Phase I trial of its lead cancer drug. It plans to complete the Phase I trial later this year and launch a Phase II study before the end of 2022.

Arcellx is developing CAR-T cancer drugs that are potentially safer and more potent than existing approved treatments. It plans to launch Phase I trials of its CAR-Ts for treating leukemia and other forms of bone marrow cancer this year.

NEA, a 19.2% pre-IPO holder, SR One (15.1%), and Novo Holdings (12.6%) are Arcellx’s top existing shareholders.

Samsara Biocapital and CAM Capital joined the registry through a $120m Series C round in June last year at private valuation of $11.55 a share.

Royal problem

So far there’s little overt suggestion the travel industry needs more equity capital, but after bridging its liquidity needs in 2020 and 2021 it is now turning its attention to post-Covid-19 balance sheet repair.

Among the hardest-hit parts and most heavily indebted parts of the industry, the cruise line operators will remain worth watching.

Though Norwegian Cruise Line has accessed ECM one way or another on five separate occasions since the onset of the pandemic in March 2020 (the last time being in November), rival Royal Caribbean has only done so once via a $1.5bn follow-on priced at $91.00 a share in March last year (Morgan Stanley and Bank of America led the offering).

In that instance, investors were a little too optimistic about the industry’s ability to put Covid-19 behind it since Royal Caribbean stock now trades at $75.58 (down 4.7% today).

Today the company revealed a Q4/full-year net loss of $1.4bn/$5.3bn and said Omicron would delay its return to profitability by a “few months” (sometime in H2 this year).

It expects to report positive operating cash flow in “late spring” as its full fleet returns to service, load factors improve and it benefits from higher prices.

Royal Caribbean carried $3.5bn of liquidity at the end of last year (down from $4.1bn at September 30) before raising another $1bn from a bond sale in early January. It has $2.3bn of debt maturities this year.

Whether the company should raise more capital didn’t come up in today’s call, though management said it would again be focused on “balance sheet improvement” in 2022.

Royal Caribbean also has a new CEO (former CFO Jason Liberty) and CFO (Naftali Holtz), which may have some bearing on whether the company is happy to keep lugging more than $20bn of long-term debt and paying a hefty quarterly interest bill of $270m-$275m.

Links

Brookfield Business Partners gets $1bn from Brookfield Asset Management to fund investments.

Cathie Wood ’s new fund to invest in private tech companies.

Advent-backed Brazilian fintech Ebanx delays US IPO.

Kohl’s adopts poison pill amid buyout offers.

Peloton Interactive draws interest from suitors, among them Amazon.

Saudi Aramco mulls $50bn stock sale, international listing.

Weekly Totals

TOTAL $1.1bn* – IPOs $209m – ABB/Blocks $0 – Follow-ons $0 – CBs $900m – SPAC IPOs $470m. International – $1bn.

*Excludes SPACs & international offerings.

Pricings

Monday

Alset Capital Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $75m IPO. 7.5m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share, one-half warrant and one-tenth right. EFH. Nasdaq “ACAXU”. Heng Fai Ambrose Chan. Real estate/proptech. 12 months. 101% in trust.

Blue World Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $80m IPO. 8m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share, one-half warrant and a one-tenth right. MAXM. Nasdaq “BWAQU”. Blue World Holdings. Travel/tourism. 12 months. 101% in trust. Priced premarket open on 1/31.

Wolfspeed (US, semiconductors) – $650m 6y cvt priced at 0.25%, up 35% versus 0.25%-0.75% and 30%-35% marketing. MS, WF, BOFA, CITI, JPM. Upsized from $500m. Capped call to $212.04, a 125% premium. Formerly Cree.

Tuesday

BRF (Brazil, meatpacker) – R$5.4bn ($1.03bn) FO. 270m shares (100% prim) at R$20.00/$3.79 versus R$21.63/$4.11 last sale and R$24.75/$4.38 at launch. CITI, BRAD, BTGP, JPM, MS, SAFRA, SANT, BOFA, CS, UBS. Global offering of local shares and 11.25m NYSE-listed ADS.

Xometry (US, 3D printing marketplace) – $250m 5y cvt priced at 1%, up 27.5% versus 0.5%-1% and 27.5%-32.5% marketing. GS, JPM.

Wednesday

Murphy Canyon Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $115m IPO. 11.5m units (100% price) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one warrant. AGP. Nasdaq “MURFU”. Presidio Property Trust. Real estate. 12 months. 102% in trust.

Thursday

Arcellx (US, biotech) – $123.8m IPO. 8.25m shares (100% prim) at $15.00 versus $15-$17 marketing. BOFA, SVBL, BARC, WBLR. Nasdaq “ACLX”. 5% DSP.

Kimbell Tiger Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $200m IPO. 20m units (100% prim) at $10.00. Each unit comprises one share and one-half warrant. UBS. NYSE “TGR.U”. Kimbell Royalty Partners. Energy, natural resources. 15 months. 103% in trust.

Silver Spike Investment (US, BDC) – $85m IPO. 6.1m shares (100% prim) at $14.00. STFL, PS. Nasdaq “SSIC”. External adviser has indicated for $50m-$60m of offering. Marketing extended from week of Jan 24. Downsized from 8.9m shares on 2/2.

Calendar

February 8: Equatorial Energia (Brazil, utility) – R$1.9bn ($350m) FO. 87.7m shares (100% prim) versus R$22.65 at launch. CS, CITI, UBS, XP, GS. 35% hot issue provision. No greenshoe.

February 10: Cariloha (US, retailer) – $32.2m IPO. 2.3m shares (100% prim) at $12-$14. ROTH, OPCO. Nasdaq Select “ALOHA”.

Withdrawn

Falcon Capital Acquisition II (US, SPAC) – $400m IPO. GS. Ariliam Group (Alan Mnuchin, Saif Rahman). Sports, media, entertainment.

Healthcare Merger II (US, SPAC) – $300m IPO. CANT. MTS Health Partners. Healthcare.

Motor City Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $250m IPO. DB, MS. Robert Wagman/Eric Singer. Auto industry.

Rocket Global Acquisition (US, SPAC) – $100m IPO. LT. Philip Wagenheim. Not defined.

The daily IFR US ECM Briefing covers US, Canadian and Latin American IPOs, as well as secondary and convertible offerings in those markets. For further information or to arrange a trial, contact client support.

For feedback, tips, people moves or anything else, please contact stephen.lacey@lseg.com, anthony.hughes1@lseg.com or robert.sherwood@lseg.com.
